entry.title: Combined summary - one-show signatures (Re: The relationship between Proof-of-Publication and Anti-Replay Oracles)
entry.summary: The conversation between Adam Back and Peter Todd revolves around the possibility of preventing double-spending in Bitcoin. Back suggests that it is possible to define a new rule where two signatures authorize something and miners can take funds, but Todd argues that clever math isn't what prevents double-spending, but rather clever economics like Bitcoin itself. He believes that presenting complex equations could potentially confuse people and obscure the more fundamental principle that math alone cannot prevent double-spending. The discussion also touches on the possibility of using math to prevent signing more than one message, with Adam suggesting that it may be sort-of possible to achieve this. Peter Todd suggests that there's no need to delve into crypto math at this stage and instead proposes using extensions to the Bitcoin scripting system to verify ECDSA signatures directly. The conversation centers around the technical aspects of implementing such changes and how they can be achieved within the existing framework. Todd emphasizes that math models reality and has no limits, so saying that math can't prevent double-spending is equivalent to saying that it cannot be done. Furthermore, he believes that it's crucial not to confuse people with complex equations that aren't relevant to the fundamental principle. Overall, the discussion highlights different perspectives on the best approach to preventing double-spending in Bitcoin, with both sides offering valid points for consideration.
